Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 04:50PM girlmace wrote: I relate so much with this subject. It makes me less alone although I empathize with all of you. My recovery (15 weeks post double mast, 2 1/2 weeks post revision surgery) has been so slow. I am young and was a triathlete right before my dx. Thank God, I can't imagine how difficult the recovery had been if I hadn't been! In some ways, I have come to terms with constant discomfort and about 50% pain (less and less but so slowly). This new year, I'm getting back into life like this isn't happening. I know that sounds a bit delusional but after so long, it's what I have to do. The best and most effective part of my recovery is 2 things; taking pain pills when needed; this saves my sanity and I'm much less grouchy with my kids and hubby and PHYSICAL THERAPY.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 11:46PM girlmace wrote: I'm so sorry for your pain and depression. I have to admit though, I'm relieve to finally find someone who is going through something similar to me. Misery loves company, you know. I am 12 weeks post bialteral, latis dorsi with bilateral SNB removal and reconstruction. I had my drains for 4 weeks. I then went in for 6 weeks to have my right side drained. Recently, my back has swelled. The ps explains that the severed nerves are tangled up with the scar tissue (that resulted from all of the aspirations) and is causing all of the pain. I said, "No shit". Anyway, he is going to anesthetise my back to "release the pain cycle". His theory is if my back can relax for a few days, perhaps the body will begin to heal itself properly. God, I'm so sick of my story of pain, but I appreciate the forum and for you reading.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 03:36PM girlmace wrote: Glycerine suppositores, recliner, and mothers-in-loves who vacuum, dust, clean toilets and CHANGE SHEETS. A TV tray by the couch and byu the bed, replacing my bedroom clock to a wall directly in front so I didn't have to turn  my body to see it, toilet paper in a basket on the floor right by the toilet, medicine bottles you don't have to push and twist to take off, and writing down times you;ve taken everything. Lots of fruit, dried fruit at first for constipation. Be OK with taking pain meds. In my case, I'm still taking them occassionally (15 weeks post 2X mx latis dors+recon). Best of luck. Always know that you are doing what you HAVE to.

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 11:51AM girlmace wrote: Ladies, Are you as frustrated as me that the docs seem to NOT KNOW really how to treat this chronic pain? I, too have been to multiple pain specialists, PTs and struggle with my GP warning me EVERY month that I might be taking too much vicodin (no more than 2/day unless pain is severe like last night). Why don't they know more? Why is there no warning? If the stats are right, anywhere  between 20-65% of women undergoing breast cancer related surgery suffer chronic pain! We deserve to NOT be in pain. We deserve to NOT be called drug addicts. The vicodin work for me. I've been perscribed so m any diff drugs and tried nerve blocks, dreaded trigger point injections and would be willing even to endure another surgery if it could help! But so far, just the vicodin helps. Of course, the pain and the drugs side effects affect me negatively in my daily life. I'm only 39. My pain specialist told me I would probably have this pain for the rest of my life!! Is there NOTHING that can be done? So frustrated and depressed this week about my GD pain!

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 08:20PM girlmace wrote: I have tears. I have felt so alone with my pain, I forgot how supportive this discussion board is. It was a life saver when I was first diagnosed and longer. Thanks for being here for me and I'm sorry that you all know what I'm talking about (another club we don't want to belong to). Getting the word out there is a great idea. Sign me up. My worst pain is not in my implant area. It's actually on my right side where my lat dorsi muscle used to be. I have a large nerve bundle (my theory, no one really seems to know) that lives there and causes me most of my vicodin pain. What is it? Why do I have it? Can I get rid of it? Why does no one know?  I sometimes have shotting pains in my armpits and around my chest up to my pectorals. I can't do push-ups or pull ups. I tried and my whole body swelled up and I was laid up for two days. WTH? Again, so nice to finally "talk" to people who truly understand how I feel. Sometimes the lonliness is the hardest part.
